document.title: Chapter 110. Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for English Language Arts and Reading Subchapter C. High School

E5ABC663281146739F0C09DD42E572F1.description: use an appropriate mode of delivery, whether written, oral, or multimodal, to present results.

112E292366DF499F9C772F5337BC96D4.description: display academic citations, including for paraphrased and quoted text, and use source materials ethically to avoid plagiarism; and

7BD4D283FEE04EE98EC48845424FDE3F.description: faulty reasoning such as ad hominem, loaded language, and slippery slope;

890444C5E5464F15B52BBA99EE0BEA55.description: credibility and bias, including omission; and

831067B556264CDD8E00269CD1D7749A.description: synthesize information from a variety of sources;

9ABAC2693D524684944B6057B333461D.description: modify the major research question as necessary to refocus the research plan;

F82A2FDFA00B4FDF9D1AE05C6400FE52.description: critique the research process at each step to implement changes as needs occur and are identified;

6FEFD35A78F7418B9584951D3BE211AC.description: develop questions for formal and informal inquiry;

35BD883167614DBEA91DBE7E19E01358.description: Inquiry and research: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts. The student engages in both short-term and sustained recursive inquiry processes for a variety of purposes. The student is expected to:

246F35CAA4D940D0BC8441DADDF46585.description: compose correspondence in a professional or friendly structure.

7C0F9C96B7244E37AA160F5C4345D0F1.description: compose argumentative texts using genre characteristics and craft; and

7364BD5163204B7F917E65ADBEEBA5EE.description: compose informational texts such as explanatory essays, reports, and personal essays using genre characteristics and craft;

0175D0BB722F4714B09418029854FED2.description: compose literary texts such as fiction and poetry using genre characteristics and craft;

E651AA7BBE9F4706A98964315691E155.description: Composition: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts--genres. The student uses genre characteristics and craft to compose multiple texts that are meaningful. The student is expected to:

F714DCDDCB544C09A8FA789FCD67C858.description: publish written work for appropriate audiences.

31E667AD356348309EEED806979BBA8B.description: punctuation, including commas, semicolons, colons, and dashes to set off phrases and clauses as appropriate; and

B2CB98EFCEB64BF98DB5818514F4DE9F.description: consistent, appropriate use of verb tense and active and passive voice;

B3126FD42E474C08B31E2D06EA97240F.description: a variety of complete, controlled sentences and avoidance of unintentional splices, run-ons, and fragments;

BEBEF13A413143A0B6B0E7D8DC61D10D.description: edit drafts using standard English conventions, including:

D29EE9ABD2A441328A50997CC26222A1.description: revise drafts to improve clarity, development, organization, style, diction, and sentence effectiveness, including use of parallel constructions and placement of phrases and dependent clauses;

BAB70C4C16F94A5F9C11B5721FDC1185.description: developing an engaging idea reflecting depth of thought with specific details, examples, and commentary;

641B44C3EEAE4573ACCCC7B2B1F12EE3.description: using an organizing structure appropriate to purpose, audience, topic, and context; and

A384A2FBAF844299822DF26DE7EAFCF1.description: develop drafts into a focused, structured, and coherent piece of writing in timed and open-ended situations by:

08BE9AA283D8406BA091753E477C7206.description: plan a piece of writing appropriate for various purposes and audiences by generating ideas through a range of strategies such as brainstorming, journaling, reading, or discussing;

C1D63F0457874FC59909D3B2F1FFC775.description: Composition: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts--writing process. The student uses the writing process recursively to compose multiple texts that are legible and use appropriate conventions. The student is expected to:

8B20C0492C2B4976A904A271045E9C71.description: explain the purpose of rhetorical devices such as understatement and overstatement and the effect of logical fallacies such as straw man and red herring arguments.

BD4F954CD5CE482596020EED0C60A07B.description: analyze how the author's diction and syntax contribute to the mood, voice, and tone of a text; and

3DA492BCA6BA499AB8B6D89ECFEBC300.description: analyze the use of literary devices such as irony and oxymoron to achieve specific purposes;

0086B882A53A412880D2FDBF4A2E2069.description: analyze how the author's use of language achieves specific purposes;

2BEF5FB8F553441C805451A7191175D5.description: evaluate the author's use of print and graphic features to achieve specific purposes;

8066868CF5DB47F188AD76530B9A8739.description: analyze use of text structure to achieve the author's purpose;

20F95FA921014A1DA28425609282E4A7.description: analyze the author's purpose, audience, and message within a text;

46BD37ED64DD498F9B2F039AE3D8B887.description: Author's purpose and craft: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts. The student uses critical inquiry to analyze the authors' choices and how they influence and communicate meaning within a variety of texts. The student analyzes and applies author's craft purposefully in order to develop his or her own products and performances. The student is expected to:

FB7CBA11FDE94278BC181E61F12CD256.description: analyze characteristics of multimodal and digital texts.

1E51EA51A6CF483C9394D976BA1070E2.description: various types of evidence and treatment of counterarguments, including concessions and rebuttals; and

3ED3125147CD41568D5F21E2CF7A9B01.description: clear arguable claim, appeals, and convincing conclusion;

7E02F2CA77E94E849420021702697239.description: analyze characteristics and structural elements of argumentative texts such as:

608C25AD3C4045C1B995643706B1D684.description: multiple organizational patterns within a text to develop the thesis;

ACDE7125E9C74AF2948E0878FC3F9EB5.description: clear thesis, relevant supporting evidence, pertinent examples, and conclusion; and

D82C9E6194184418844EE7FD7DAA1C27.description: analyze characteristics and structural elements of informational texts such as:

F3E077A4865F429888364A7E29237906.description: analyze the function of dramatic conventions such as asides, soliloquies, dramatic irony, and satire;

0B61CBE46E044748A1C6A1F02AF51A34.description: analyze the structure, prosody, and graphic elements such as line length and word position in poems across a variety of poetic forms;

BDE8847CE77E4B768D85E423CDCF8EBE.description: read and respond to American, British, and world literature;

0CCA78E88AAC45CAB17D9C2BEEC08AF5.description: Multiple genres: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts--genres. The student recognizes and analyzes genre-specific characteristics, structures, and purposes within and across increasingly complex traditional, contemporary, classical, and diverse texts. The student is expected to:

9A2A75025DA3463B930C493AB9053C16.description: analyze how the setting influences the theme.

ED7BC6E4337B4E9889E2AB067157A1D0.description: analyze non-linear plot development such as flashbacks, foreshadowing, subplots, and parallel plot structures and compare it to linear plot development; and

507633F244654D30BB6A359AA683CD9E.description: analyze how authors develop complex yet believable characters in works of fiction through a range of literary devices, including character foils;

921009FB2B6A4B07B628810E0EC00346.description: analyze how themes are developed through characterization and plot in a variety of literary texts;

48CB8135A61C49BF8307394277B074D2.description: Multiple genres: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts--literary elements. The student recognizes and analyzes literary elements within and across increasingly complex traditional, contemporary, classical, and diverse literary texts. The student is expected to:

7661CAA2C13D4DACAF0B03F47142A531.description: defend or challenge the authors' claims using relevant text evidence.

7C2141BB20B24C94A8D8EBF4E00EB17D.description: reflect on and adjust responses when valid evidence warrants; and

62A2A4BD861542E8BFBC40ECAD2552EE.description: respond orally or in writing with appropriate register, vocabulary, tone, and voice;

2232A8ECC2A24D45A3F848253123F0AA.description: discuss and write about the explicit or implicit meanings of text;

6C45CCB19ABB4918B1F7DCB686DA2CB1.description: respond using acquired content and academic vocabulary as appropriate;

D8FE39F60E5B4979999EDDDB2D2AA39D.description: interact with sources in meaningful ways such as notetaking, annotating, freewriting, or illustrating;

F96990ADBF1A469793A123AA47146619.description: paraphrase and summarize texts in ways that maintain meaning and logical order;

4D42F1A4B9DB4259AA44D1D55B970CCC.description: use text evidence and original commentary to support a comprehensive response;

D510DCFEA418457C8491C06F476BA0CC.description: write responses that demonstrate understanding of texts, including comparing texts within and across genres;

DC7E81E8B70943DDA438A4B81D8CA73A.description: describe personal connections to a variety of sources, including self-selected texts;

D43A463E14AD470B9E7BF0E3BCF6C70C.description: Response skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts. The student responds to an increasingly challenging variety of sources that are read, heard, or viewed. The student is expected to:

BD6FF56E309947638D51A2EB1797FB5B.description: monitor comprehension and make adjustments such as re-reading, using background knowledge, asking questions, and annotating when understanding breaks down.

4A25AF11653F42CC8A9157E94D534709.description: synthesize information from two texts to create new understanding; and

C08997AA95E54B2B9A6D6EC93CBC3C12.description: evaluate details read to determine key ideas;

E5595B0251A04567804D697398DE1056.description: make inferences and use evidence to support understanding;

ECEB8D7C1E9A42EEAC3578C1FAA21D56.description: make connections to personal experiences, ideas in other texts, and society;

512A7CDF406E4863A7D5E807FEC8474E.description: create mental images to deepen understanding;

101902AFF0C14AC9AFDA277853FAF68C.description: make and correct or confirm predictions using text features, characteristics of genre, and structures;

A8C2A8C98B864645A0B731527C9C28A2.description: generate questions about text before, during, and after reading to deepen understanding and gain information;

0736CE033C0147DA92622B78ADDB9BA6.description: establish purpose for reading assigned and self-selected texts;

3464523004DB467C8F2ACBC3EFDF0CA5.description: Comprehension skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts. The student uses metacognitive skills to both develop and deepen comprehension of increasingly complex texts. The student is expected to:

E81343D2872F4C0193BD6C42BCA68FED.description: Developing and sustaining foundational language skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking--self-sustained reading. The student reads grade-appropriate texts independently. The student is expected to self-select text and read independently for a sustained period of time.

342054BC012D428091B67AC94527542D.description: determine the meaning of foreign words or phrases used frequently in English such as bona fide, caveat, carte blanche, tête-à-tête, bon appétit, and quid pro quo.

5CFA109D44704495B398813BDD54D92D.description: analyze context to distinguish between the denotative and connotative meanings of words; and

B4920E979DC14587BC2E8C8E7096C11D.description: use print or digital resources such as glossaries or technical dictionaries to clarify and validate understanding of the precise and appropriate meaning of technical or discipline-based vocabulary;

9E2DB9869C444FE9ABC14EA5AFC2B739.description: Developing and sustaining foundational language skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking--vocabulary. The student uses newly acquired vocabulary expressively. The student is expected to:

9AF3DE458DAB4A80A32016ECCBD65B96.description: participate collaboratively, building on the ideas of others, contributing relevant information, developing a plan for consensus building, and setting ground rules for decision making.

DA3F7588230C4C108199B215DB199A7A.description: give a presentation using informal, formal, and technical language effectively to meet the needs of audience, purpose, and occasion, employing eye contact, speaking rate such as pauses for effect, volume, enunciation, purposeful gestures, and conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively; and

5B7B9C7D29B0422AA8E106A14EA2E263.description: follow and give complex oral instructions to perform specific tasks, answer questions, or solve problems and complex processes;

CBD7FB25BF3A49BA81E906484665420F.description: engage in meaningful and respectful discourse by listening actively, responding appropriately, and adjusting communication to audiences and purposes;

5109A567E4FC467089082120F946256A.description: Developing and sustaining foundational language skills: listening, speaking, discussion, and thinking--oral language. The student develops oral language through listening, speaking, and discussion. The student is expected to:
